Function.Description: The kurtosis function determines the peakedness or flatness of the distribution curve defined by a set of data points.

Brief.Overview: The kurtosis function determines the peakedness or flatness of the distribution curve defined by a set of data points. A normal distribution has a kurtosis of 0. A negative kurtosis value describes a distribution that is flatter than normal (platykurtic); a positive kurtosis value describes a distribution more peaked than normal (leptokurtic).
Brief.Usage: The kurtosis function is used to compute the peakedness or flatness of the distribution curve defined by a set of data points.

Syntax.Return: Returns a number corresponding to the the peakedness or flatness of the distribution curve defined by a set of data points. Any arguments that cannot be evaluated as numbers are ignored in the calculation of kurtosis. Also, if there are less than four data points or if the sample standard deviation is zero, the kurtosis function returns an error value.
